title: Woman chooses to undergo drastic chemical menopause at 24 after 'unbelievable' pain
text:

A young woman has chosen to go through the menopause for a second time aged just 24.

Chanelle Urquhart took the drastic decision to undergo 'chemical menopause' in a bid to end months of horrific pain caused by endometriosis.

The process will see the woman from Hull injected with hormones that stop ovulation and menstruation.

After being diagnosed with the condition, which causes the lining of the womb to grow across internal organs, last year, Chanelle says 'switching off' her hormones has been completely worth it.

The bartender first went through the menopause aged 22 but chose to have further treatment this year in a bid to stop the production of oestrogen.

(Image: Caters News Agency)

(Image: Caters News Agency)

She said: “The pains in my stomach were constant and it felt like there was a tiny person inside my stomach who was swinging a knife around.

“Endometriosis began taking over my life, I had to defer my second year at university studying biomedical science because of my mental health, the pain and I had my operation coming up to remove part of my cervix as severe abnormal cells were found on my first smear.

“Depression and anxiety come hand in hand with endometriosis as the pain is unbelievable and you’re constantly worrying about what is going to happen next.

“It felt a bit weird going through the menopause at such a young age because it is usually older women, but it stopped my period which is a huge relief.

“The first time I was given an induced menopause by a monthly injection was two years ago, but it affected my mood more than ever.

“This year in April, I was given a nasal spray that induces the menopause which is much better because I can look after my mental health and stop spraying it each month if I feel the same as last time.

(Image: Caters News Agency)

(Image: Caters News Agency)

“I do get hot flushes and extreme memory loss but at least my iron levels are back up and I’m not bed bound.”

The severity of endometriosis began when Chanelle started her periods at 12 but she was dismissed by doctors and says she was made to feel as though she was ‘exaggerating’.

She was forced to take a daily cocktail of painkillers including Tramadol in a bid to reduce her lower abdomen, leg and back pain.

She adds: “I have spent most of my life going back and forth from the doctors who made me feel like I was going insane as they said it is ‘period pains’ and a few have said it was an STI.

“The results would always come back negative and I always knew there was something wrong, but I started to think maybe they’re right and I am being a hypochondriac.

(Image: Caters News Agency)

“I was finally taken seriously when I got into my twenties and I have had two laparoscopy’s with excision of endometriosis - a surgical procedure, enabling them to see my organs and remove what they can.

“But as it took so long, they discovered the endometriosis had spread to my bowel, womb, ovaries and all over my pelvic wall.

“I also had blood filled cysts in my ovaries that would burst up to once a month and I imagine the pain would be like someone pouring acid over my organs, thankfully the endometriosis has since been removed via surgery.

“The induced menopause doesn’t stop my daily pain which is why I take Tramadol, but it stops my horrendous periods and stops the endometriosis from growing.

“If the pain continues, I will consider a hysterectomy in the future even though it's not a cure as endometriosis can grow on any organ, but it is an option to relieve some pain.

“I am sharing my story as I feel there needs to be more awareness around this disease, so many women with these symptoms are getting fobbed off by their doctors and treated like they're making it up like I did.”
description: Chanelle Urquhart will be injected with hormones that stop ovulation and menstruation in a bid to escape pain from endometriosis
